channel.title: Tops on The RangeShifter platform
channel.description: Recent content in Tops on The RangeShifter platform

item.description: About RangeShifter As anthropogenic environmental changes accelerate and threaten speciesâ€™ persistence and associated ecosystem services, major tasks for scientists are to predict biological responses to different and interacting pressures, and to design effective management strategies. Process-based models that explicitly integrate the different processes underpinning the responses of complex biological systems are now increasingly called for and provide opportunities (and challenges) to rapidly move forward in this endeavour (Urban et al.

The RangeShifter GUI The RangeShifter platform was first published in Bocedi et al. (2014). The software is coded in C++ and packaged as a freely available Windows GUI. The graphical user interface is particularly useful for initial model exploration and for demonstration and teaching purposes. For more complex or computationally demanding simulations, it can also be run in Batch mode. RangeShifter v1.0 is accompanied by extensive documentation. For getting acquainted with the software, we recommend to first read the manual to understand the conceptual underpinnings of RangeShifter, and then run the tutorials offered in the manual.

The RangeshiftR package We here introduce the new RangeshiftR package, which makes RangeShifter available from within R. The R package makes it especially easy to run more complex simulations, it allows more coherent workflows and easier reproducability as well as integration with other Rpackages and plotting functions. Please note that the RangeshiftR package is not yet released and only available as beta version upon request. The official release is planned for May 2020.

Tutorials Both the RangeShifter GUI and the RangeshiftR package come with extensive documentation and tutorials. We also offer regular workshop on using the software, which we will also advertise on this website. The tutorials lead you step by step through the example applications described in Bocedi et al. (2014): Tutorial 1: range expansions and long-distance dispersal Tutorial 2: patch connectivity using different dispersal and settlement rules Tutorial 3: evolution of dispersal strategies during range shifting We recommend to carefully read the manual to understand the conceptual underpinnings of RangeShifter.
